question: 6 (a)
sols_html:
Using separation of variables we can write

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{dh}{dt} = -kh^{1/3}\end{aligned}\]

as

\[\begin{aligned} h^{-1/3}\,dh = -k\,dt, \quad \text{which we integrate to get} \quad \int h^{-1/3}\,dh = \int -k\,dt.\end{aligned}\]

Both integrals are solved straight forward to yield

\[\begin{aligned} \frac32 h^{2/3} = -kT+C_1\end{aligned}\]

which we solve for h to obtain

\[\begin{aligned} h(t) = \left(C_2 - \frac23 kt\right)^{3/2},\end{aligned}\]

where C2 is another constant.

All that’s left to do now is to use the initial condition h(0) = h0 to solve for C2:

\[\begin{aligned} h_0 = h(0) = \left(C_2-\frac23k\cdot 0\right)^{3/2}, \quad \text{which yields} \quad C_2 = h_0^{2/3}.\end{aligned}\]

Therefore the height h(t) at any time t is given by

\[\begin{aligned} h(t) = \left(h_0^{2/3}-\frac23 kt\right)^{3/2}.\end{aligned}\]

To double-check your answer you can take the derivative of h(t) and check that the given differential equation is indeed satisfied:

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{dh}{dt} &= \frac32\left(h_0^{2/3}-\frac23 kt\right)^{1/2} \cdot \left(-\frac23 k\right) \\ &= -k \underbrace{\left(h_0^{2/3}-\frac23 kt\right)^{1/2}}_{= h^{1/3}}\end{aligned}\]
sols_raw:
Using separation of variables we can write

:<math> \frac{dh}{dt} = -kh^{1/3} </math>

as

:<math> h^{-1/3}\,dh = -k\,dt, \quad \text{which we integrate to get} \quad \int h^{-1/3}\,dh = \int -k\,dt. </math>

Both integrals are solved straight forward to yield

:<math> \frac32 h^{2/3} = -kT+C_1 </math>

which we solve for ''h'' to obtain

:<math> h(t) = \left(C_2 - \frac23 kt\right)^{3/2}, </math>

where ''C<sub>2</sub>'' is another constant.

All that's left to do now is to use the initial condition ''h(0) = h<sub>0</sub>'' to solve for ''C<sub>2</sub>'':

:<math> h_0 = h(0) = \left(C_2-\frac23k\cdot 0\right)^{3/2}, \quad \text{which yields} \quad C_2 = h_0^{2/3}. </math>

Therefore the height ''h(t)'' at any time ''t'' is given by

:<math> h(t) = \left(h_0^{2/3}-\frac23 kt\right)^{3/2}. </math>



''To double-check your answer you can take the derivative of h(t) and check that the given differential equation is indeed satisfied:''

:<math> \begin{align}
\frac{dh}{dt} &= \frac32\left(h_0^{2/3}-\frac23 kt\right)^{1/2} \cdot \left(-\frac23 k\right) \\
&= -k \underbrace{\left(h_0^{2/3}-\frac23 kt\right)^{1/2}}_{= h^{1/3}}
\end{align}
</math>
statement_html:
The height of fluid, \(h(t)\) in a cylindrical container is controlled by a pump so that it satisfies the differential equation

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{dh}{dt} = -kh^{1/3}, \quad h(0)=h_0\end{aligned}\]

where \(k>0\), \(h_0>0\) are constants, and \(h_0\) is the initial height of the fluid.

(a) Solve this differential equation to determine the height \(h(t)\) at any later time \(t\).
statement_latex:
The height of fluid, $h(t)$ in a cylindrical container is controlled by
a pump so that it satisfies the differential equation

\begin{align*}
\frac{dh}{dt} = -kh^{1/3}, \quad h(0)=h_0
\end{align*} where $k>0$, $h_0>0$ are
constants, and $h_0$ is the initial height of the fluid.

(a) Solve this differential equation to determine the height $h(t)$ at
any later time $t$.
statement_raw:
The height of fluid, <math>h(t)</math> in a cylindrical container is controlled by a pump so that it satisfies the differential equation
:<math> \frac{dh}{dt} = -kh^{1/3}, \quad h(0)=h_0 </math>
where <math>k>0</math>, <math>h_0>0</math> are constants, and <math>h_0</math> is the initial height of the fluid.

(a) Solve this differential equation to determine the height <math>h(t)</math> at any later time <math>t</math>.
